sen.j: 祇園神社（ぎおんじんじゃ）は、祇園信仰のための神社。
sen.e: Gion-jinja Shrines are Shinto shrines dedicated to the Gion Faith.

sen.j: 名称は、神仏分離以前に現在主祭神とされているスサノオが祇園精舎の守護神である牛頭天王と同一視され祀られていたことから来ている。
sen.e: The name of these shrines derives from before the separation of Shinto and Buddhism when the current main deity Susanoo was believed to also be Gozu Tennou, the protective deity of Gion Shoja (Jetavana Grove).

sen.j: 同様の信仰を持ち、「牛頭天王社」と称する神社も多かった。
sen.e: There are also many Shinto shrines dedicated to the same faith with the name "Gozu Tenno-sha".

sen.j: 明治に神仏分離が行われた際、仏教の神である牛頭天王は祭神から外され神道の神であるスサノオが残ったが、同時に多くの神社名から仏教用語の「祇園」や「牛頭天王」が外され、総本社である京都の祇園神社も八坂神社と改名された。
sen.e: When the separation of Buddhism and Shinto occurred during the Meiji era, the Buddhist deity Gozu Tenno was removed from this shrine to leave only the Shinto deity Susanoo but during this time there were also many other shrines from which Buddhist terms such as "Gion" and "Gozu Tenno" were removed from the shrine name - including the head shrine in Kyoto which had its name changed from "Gion-jinja Shrine" to "Yasaka-jinja Shrine".

sen.j: しかし神社の名前が変更されても、地名としての祇園や奉納される祭の「祇園祭」、「祇園御霊会」といった呼称、また神社の愛称としての「祇園さん」等が残っている地域は多い。
sen.e: However, there are many cases in which the place name "Gion", the "Gion Matsuri" and "Gion Goryo-e" festivals and the affectionate shrine name "Gion-san" were not changed even when the name of the shrine was changed.
